Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Designing the Impact Studio -- Dynamic Visualizations in the Write4Change Networked Community

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by engaging them in quantitative data analysis to support their own communication skills. The amount and variety of information generated and shared online requires young people to be adept at effectively producing, analyzing, assessing, using, visualizing, and circulating data. They must be data literate. This project investigates how adolescents develop data literacy by teaching young people to analyze their own online participation and to learn how to make their digital footprints have greater impact. Specifically, researchers will build and test a suite of visualization tools called the "Impact Studio" that will give students access to data about their online interactions. The "Impact Studio" will be developed and tested with students and educators who participate in a global online community called "Write4Change" (W4C). In this virtual community, youth and their teachers communicate online about issues of local and global concern -- for example, climate change, immigration, peace and conflict -- and explore how their own ideas and activities can contribute to solutions. Using the "Impact Studio," students will learn to deploy data visualizations as a means to test, revise, and more clearly express their concepts and proposals. Designing, developing, and testing digital tools that support students in becoming productive, civically engaged 21st century citizens, this project will contribute to scientific knowledge about how young people learn to strategically leverage data in order to produce, assess, and circulate information in a global arena.

As a design-based research study, the project develops and tests theories about how youth engage in data literacy practices to write for impact. Though the use of data is an essential part of analyzing, producing, and circulating information in STEM fields, this study broadens that focus to consider how the strategic use of data can inform digital writing. Across four iterative design phases that focus on building, testing, enhancing, and implementing the integrated visualization tools in the Impact Studio, the researchers will study 1) how the Impact Studio's visualized data displays influence student collaboration; 2) how students use data from the Impact Studio in communicating cross-culturally; and 3) how the capacity to create, critique, and manage multimodal representations allows students to leverage visualized data in their writing process (including the content of what they write, how they share and circulate their writing, and how they revise). The research team will first conduct design workshops and user testing on a prototype to refine the feature requirements for Version 1 of the Impact Studio. Researchers will then collect quantitative and qualitative data that track network activity and Impact Studio usage from W4C members (including interviews; participant observation; content analysis; temporal, frequency, citation, and interaction data from the network; surveys; digital competencies; skill inventories; and knowledge measures). After a period of data analysis, tool redesign, and user testing, the research team will undertake another period of data collection and analysis. This project will develop key principles about how to support students in generating and navigating vast amounts of data, critically interpreting and creating visual and textual representations of those data, and measuring the impact of their work on cross-cultural audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated how adolescents developed data literacy by building a suite of visualization tools called the "Impact Studio.” The Impact Studio was developed and tested with students and educators who participated in the global online community called Write4Change. In this virtual community, youth and their teachers communicated online about issues of local and global concern -- for example, climate change, immigration, peace and conflict -- and explored how their own ideas and activities can contribute to solutions, particularly through their networked writing. We studied 1) how the Impact Studio's visualized data displays influenced student collaboration; 2) how students used data from the Impact Studio in communicating cross-culturally; and 3) how the capacity to create, critique, and manage multimodal representations allowed students to leverage visualized data in their writing process (including the content of what they write, how they share and circulate their writing, and how they revise).


We found that participants primarily used the Impact Studio tools to learn more about one another, and that these tools were sensitive enough to capture some of the more ‘silent’ forms of participation and collaboration that might otherwise be overlooked. For example, students spent most of their time (62% across the life of the network) viewing each other’s materials rather than liking, commenting, pinning, or remixing it (the other, and more visible, options in the network). Through the student-facing data analytics, youth were made aware of these patterns of participation (their own and others) and often used that information to reach out to unknown others or to become more visible in their activity (e.g., making a comment vs.simply viewing). The most popular visualizations were those that helped students understand their audience, such as the network visualization that allowed them to see an real-time graph of networked connections so they could glean, at-a-glance, whom they had interacted with over time. In the cross-cultural network, it was immediately visible on the graph tool that many participants stuck close to their existing friend networks, while a few ‘super-connectors’ were hubs for cross-cultural activity across sites. Students reported being motivated by these visualized insights, both in terms of the content they produced and shared (e.g., sharing more visual data to support multilingual participants) as well as in the kinds of activity they participated in on the network (e.g., reaching out to new people they did not already know). In addition to being the most used, these ‘audience’ oriented visualization tools were reported to be most valuable by participants. 


While these visualizations were appreciated and consulted by participants at different times and for different purposes, ultimately a number found the tools an ‘extra’ bonus but not central to the network. Students understood the central purpose of the community to revolve around cross-cultural communication and collaboration, and they did not immediately see the usefulness of visualized data for those purposes. For example, students did not often go to the Impact Studio of their own accord and when they did, they reported that the data did not often guide their writing, revising, or decision-making. Part of the challenge was where these tools were located. Since the studio offered multiple visualization tools in one page, students had to specifically navigate there. In contrast, one of the tools, an activity tracker, was embedded with every piece of posted media, and students reported finding that just-in-time kind of data much more usable and helpful. Not only did the tracker offer information about who had interacted with a piece of content over time, but it was immediately visible how the audience had done so historically (e.g., viewed, commented, etc.). Students reported this kind of embedded tool offered more actionable data when they needed it (e.g., to decide what to do with a piece of media). A second part of the challenge revolved around students not knowing how this visualized data could be useful toward the broader goal of the network, particularly in revising or composing their writing. We found that sustained and targeted curricular intervention was successful at addressing this challenge, particularly curriculum that helped students move from interpreting the data, which they were quite capable of doing, to understanding how to use the data for multiple purposes, particularly in shaping rhetorical purpose and tracing uptake. 


In analyzing data across four design phases, we have sought to understand broadly what it means to ‘write for impact’, developing a more sociocultural model that brings together behavioral, affective, and relational dimensions of impact to understand how, why, and under what conditions ideas, people, and texts circulate across networks and the affects/effects.
